stem: A newborn is being evaluated for a suspected congenital heart defect. Highlight the findings that are characteristic of coarctation of the aorta.
passage: The nurse is performing a newborn assessment. Vital signs show a [blood pressure of 94/62 mmHg in the right arm] and [64/42 mmHg in the right leg]. The nurse notes that the [brachial and radial pulses are full and bounding], while the [femoral and pedal pulses are weak and difficult to palpate]. The nurse observes [skin that is pale and cool in the lower extremities]. Upon auscultation, a [systolic murmur is heard best at the left infraclavicular area] and [radiates to the back]. The newborn has [mild tachypnea] at 62 breaths/min. When the infant cries, the [upper body appears flushed] while the [lower body remains pale].

rationale.correct: Coarctation of the aorta is a narrowing of the aorta that restricts blood flow to the lower body. The hallmark includes high BP/bounding pulses in the upper extremities and low BP/weak pulses in the lower extremities. This leads to cooler, paler lower extremities. A systolic murmur radiating to the back is common. Flushed upper body versus pale lower body (differential cyanosis/perfusion) confirms the localized nature of the obstruction.
rationale.incorrect: The fact that the nurse is performing a newborn assessment is the context.
rationale.clinicalPearls: Screening for coarctation is done by comparing upper and lower extremity blood pressures or pulse oximetry. A difference of >10 mmHg between upper and lower extremity BP is significant.
rationale.questionTrap: Upper Body = Bounding/High BP. Lower Body = Weak/Low BP.

reviewUnits.heading: Coarctation Assessment
reviewUnits.body: Look for BP and pulse discrepancies between upper and lower extremities.

answerBreakdown.label: Critical Cues
answerBreakdown.content: The identified evidence represents objective clinical markers of physiological instability.
